issues.title: Bug 1426105 - Make elimination branch detection work with find fix runs.
issues.body:
Call _reverse_if_find_fix() when there is no explicit branch in commit message,
so find fix runs can continue onto integration branches.

Bug 1234029 - use debug builds from archives.m.o
issues.body:
For firefox and jsshell, provides access to debug builds using
archives.m.o.

Those builds are stored using 'debug' in their filename, and
using TaskCluster is not required anymore.

commit.message: Bug 1414879 - Avoid privacy notice on every launch (#473)

Fix typo in message about 64-bit systems (#472)

Right now the message about default build type (64-bit vs. 32-bit) incorrectly refers to them as "64 bits" and "32 bits".  The correct/common adjective for these types of builds are "64-bit" vs. "32-bit" (singular bits, and with a hyphen).  See e.g. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/switch-32-bit-64-bit as one reference on this language.

Bug 1278683 - Update config and build info handling

Update config and build info handling

Taskcluster routes (for linux64 debug at least) have temporarily changed
from using 'debug' to 'dbg'. Eventually this behavior will revert but
for now we need to special case it.

Additionally the binary archive name for builds in taskcluster has
changed from specifying the platform and architecture to just using a
generic term, 'target', for all platforms. The build regex has been
updated to handle that behavior.

Bug 1245332 - stopping firefox may hang on windows

On windows, if a firefox build is stopped after it had restarted (from
Menu (≡) -> [?] -> Restart with Add-ons Disabled for example) it will
hang for a couple of minutes.

The blocking comes from mozprocess, but it is quite hard to fix properly,
and it is a corner case - so here is a workaround patch.

It run the stop method in a thread, and wait 0.7 seconds for its
completion. If the thread is not terminated after that, we simply forget
it, so it will be finished later (abruptly in case the program ends
before the completion).

Bug 1245335 - use android-api-15 for recent fennec builds

For both archives.m.o and taskcluster, fennec route names have changed since
around 2016-01-29 - and mozregression can't find recent builds because
of that.

This patch should solve the issue by using api-15 instead of api-11
after this date.

Bug 1245333 - [gui] wrong build for retry

We calculate the middle of the build range to know which build should be
run.
In case a retry is done after a skip, this lead to an error - so for the
retry action we should not calculate the middle again, just reuse the
previous one.

I took the opportunity to clean the mid/self.mid redundancy in the code.

Bug 1229976 - use json-pushes to determine arange

Uses json-pushes API to determine the date range. Before we were trying
to find such a range by trying to map a date to a changeset - but this
is error prone (in case we have no changeset for date limit) and we were
doing three requests.

Now only one request is sufficient - and we let json-pushes handle the
corner cases described above.

Also, I added some logging statements. And now pushes
from *pushlog_within_changes* are sorted by pushid, instead of
date (note that it should not change anything, but this is more logical).

Bug 1095058 - new bisection workflow

Merge branch 'new-workflow'. See commits in there for details.

Basically, mozregression now try to detect merge commits and will bisect
in the origin branch in that case. It will no longer bisect on
mozilla-inbound automatically.

The --inbound-branch option becomes obsolete then so it is removed.

Aliases can be used now (m-i, m-c, inbound, central, ...)
Nicer error message on switch branch failure

add tests for the branches module
[GUI] Automatically bisect integration branch on merge

Automatically bisect integration branch on merge

This change the workflow of mozregression (non GUI for now).

Basically, when we finish a nightly bisection, we switch to taskcluster
bisection to reduce the range on the same branch.

Once this is reduced to two push (that is one good, one bad), we parse
the log message and try to detect a merge. If we find a merge, we
continue the bisection on the branch where the merged commits comes from.

create a branches module

This allow to use more than just integration branches using
--good-rev/--bad-rev and --inbound-branch, like m-c.

Bug 1217906 - allow to find build using build ids

This allow in --good-date, --bad-date, --launch to use a given buildid.

It works for nightlies only, as finding the buildid relies on the folder
name in archives.m.o.

A known bug is that files are stored using the build id, so it is
possible to have two files downloaded and kept in the persist dir
that are identical, example:

2015-11-03-03-02-48--mozilla-central--firefox-45.0a1.en-US.linux-x86_64.tar.bz2
2015-11-03--mozilla-central--firefox-45.0a1.en-US.linux-x86_64.tar.bz2

issue_comments.body: Great addition!

Thanks! I'll take a look at this. Just FYI Github stuff:

for other projects, it's better to do this kind of work in a remote branch that isn't master, in case the upstream doesn't take your changes and your master becomes dirty.

Also, you don't need to make a new pull request if you want to add another commit, a pull request will pick up any new commits to the branch you made the pull request from.
made the requested changes and squashed again to keep things clean
Thank you _so_ much for this pull request. I've merged it and uploaded mozregression 0.5.2 to pypi.
Fantastic change, thank you!
Merged, thanks! I changed the slashes to commas in the printout though, I thought it was a bit more English-y for the manual testers.

Makes total sense to change that URL. Can you also watch out for other left-overs? At least I have found one in:
https://raw.github.com/mozilla/mozregression/master/README.md

Would be good to get them fixed in one patch.
That is on a different branch so would have to be fixed in a different pull request from what I understand.
Oh, right. Sorry that I missed that. Looks good to me then. Mind landing yourself?
I would if I had access
I did it for you now. Thanks for the patch Matt.
I agree with wlach that mozdevice would be better.
I'm going to go ahead and merge and write a follow-up issue.  If this helps testing now, that's a plus, and the mozregression code is not exactly wonderful as is
see also https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/issues/44
@k0s, it would be great if we could merge --squash pull requests in the future to avoid interim states of the fix landing on the official branches.

I'm not really interested in expending the extra effort to do this.  I inherited maintaining mozregression and have kept the workflow ABICT that is neither documented nor specified anywhere: namely, the typical github workflow == github issues + pull requests.  Quite frankly, I don't like or approve of either of these.  For some reason, github does not have a squash option wrt pull requests. This is one of the things I pretty much consider part of accepting 3rd party workflow. I am perfectly willing to turn project management over to someone that has more time.

That said, none of this is really germaine to his issue or pull request.

So it looks like I bitrotted you :( my apologies.  Could you rejigger the thingies so that it works?

Also, ABICT, we don't need any of the self.binary logic found in Nightly.**init** anymore.  Assuming my assessment is accurate, could we remove?

So I think you need to close this pull request before I can make another.

I've included your updates above in my forked repo and also added the changes to re-fix Issue #33.

Also, I left in the self.binary under FennecNightly as a comment because I wasn't sure if this uses a different binary location. I can remove it if you'd like. `mozregression --app=fennec` doesn't seem to work on my system.

Let me know if I need to do anything else.

Looks good, if rather hard to read since for reasons I don't understand github displays the code from commits already in master o_O . The android issue will have to be looked at; tbh, I haven't tried mozregression with android.  You are indeed correct that self-binary should be handled separately for these cases.  I'll do a follow up for that.  In any case, its probably easiest to merge this end and deal with the fall-out.

(Also, in the future, please test changes when possible)

gah, by which i mean: https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/commit/6569504fd82a208520805acfd0ba07a270e356d4
Mac apparently is relying on this code: https://github.com/mozilla/mozbase/blob/master/mozrunner/mozrunner/runner.py#L89
Good catch!  That would indeed explain things
@k0s Thanks for the feedback. I'll make the changes and re-send the pull request.
This wfm.  I'd like to see force32bits deprecated in the future.

Sorry, I should have been more specific.  I would like https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/pull/53/files#L0R183 to work more like runnightly and have --bits={32,64} (on systems where it makes sense, anyway) with the default being chosen based on some sort of common sense.

I would probably just do options.bits = int(options.bits) instead of the parseBits function

> Would that also require a change here: https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/blob/master/mozregression/regression.py#L81 or not?

Probably.  Will need to look at MozCommitBuilder to figure out if that is supported yet or not.

> instead of the parseBits function

I used the function because we have the extra bit of logic for not allowing 64 bit to be specified on a 32 bit system here:

https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/pull/54/files#L1R273

Although I think it would be simpler to have written the function like so:

```
def parseBits(optionBits):
    """returns the correctly typed bits"""
    if optionBits == "32":
        return 32
    else:
        # if 64 bits is passed on a 32 bit system, it won't be honored
        return mozinfo.bits
```
wfm
lgtm

This looks good!
I just noted something on the PR, you forgot to handle the --pref argument.
Also, the pref object needs do be added here (in launcher_kwargs): https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/pull/190/files#diff-9ca866adb100de14c577141d9b0d6b67R245, else it does not have any effect.

Do I have to add in the following way: 
prefs = options.pref ? or prefs = mozprofile.prefs.Preferences() ?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/1974980/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/1974980)

Coverage increased (+0.12%) to 91.91% when pulling **77b590574ebfcc02c531fcf66aea274ba24175bf on jpigree:master** into **741bfe1f7bdce138cb1e4211ee1fe907ad32ab30 on mozilla:master**.

You have to add the created prefs object like this:

launcher_kwargs = dict(
addons=options.addons,
profile=options.profile,
cmdargs=options.cmdargs,
preferences=prefs,
)

This is because the variable launcher_kwargs will then be passed here : https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/blob/master/mozregression/test_runner.py#L29, then we will use it here: https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/blob/master/mozregression/test_runner.py#L131 and finally it will override the default that you just added here: https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/pull/190/files#diff-9be3d66461b771098aa1bcc305505480R113

This is how your prefs object will end up in the launchers.MozRunnerLauncher._start method.

Tell me if it is not clear, I think it is pretty important to understand this.

+class InboundBuilData(object):
+    """
+    Represents the inbound build data avalaible, designed to be used in
+    bisection.
+
+    It allow the lazy loading of build data, by fetching only lower bound,
+    higher bound and center when required.
+
+    As some build folders are not valid - and we can know that only
+    after really fetching data - there is some imprecision on data
+    size which may reduce when you call ensure_limits or center.
+

+     - len(data) # size

+    def _fetch(self, ids):
+        """
+        Internal method to fetch some data.
+        """
+        # filter the already downloaded data
+        builds_to_get = [i for i in ids if self[i] is None]
+
+        with futures.ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=8) as executor:
+            futures_results = {}
+            for i in builds_to_get:
+                build_url, timestamp = self._cache[i][1], self._cache[i][2]
+                future = executor.submit(self._get_valid_build,
+                                         build_url,
+                                         timestamp,
+                                         self.raw_revisions)
+                futures_results[future] = i
+            for future in futures.as_completed(futures_results):
+                i = futures_results[future]
+                if future.exception() is not None:
+                    sys.exit("Retrieving valid builds from %r generated an"
+                             " exception: %s" % (self._cache[i][1],
+                                                 future.exception()))
+                self._cache[i][0] = future.result()
+        # filter the builds that were invalids
+        self._cache = [c for c in self._cache if c[0] is not False]
+
+    def _get_valid_build(self, build_url, timestamp, raw_revisions):
review_comments.body: While we're here, could you add some retry logic in this method in case it fails?

+class InboundBuilData(object):
+    """
+    Represents the inbound build data avalaible, designed to be used in
+    bisection.
+
+    It allow the lazy loading of build data, by fetching only lower bound,
+    higher bound and center when required.
+
+    As some build folders are not valid - and we can know that only
+    after really fetching data - there is some imprecision on data
+    size which may reduce when you call ensure_limits or center.
+
+    An instance of InboundBuilData acts like a list, ensuring following methods:
+     - len(data) # size
+     - data[1:]  # splice
+     - data[0]   # get data
+    """
+    def __init__(self, cache, raw_revisions, window_range=4):
+        self._cache = cache
+        self.raw_revisions = raw_revisions
+        self.window_range = window_range
+
+    def __len__(self):
+        return len(self._cache)
+
+    def __getslice__(self, smin, smax):
+        return InboundBuilData(self._cache[smin:smax],
+                               self.raw_revisions,
+                               window_range=self.window_range)
+
+    def __getitem__(self, i):
+        return self._cache[i][0]
+
+    def ensure_limits(self):
+        """
+        Ensure we know the min and max data, fetching it if necessary.
+        """
+        while True:
+            # first we detect if we need to fetch, and which build ids
+            range_min = []
+            range_max = []
+
+            size = len(self)
+            if self[0] is None:
+                # we need to fetch the lower data limit
+                bound = min(size, self.window_range*2)
+                range_min.extend(range(0, bound))
+            if self[-1] is None:
+                # we need to fetch the higher data limit
+                bound = max(0, size - self.window_range*2)
+                range_max.extend(range(bound, size))
+
+            # restrict the number of builds to fetch
review_comments.body:
This way if the lower bound is not needed for example, the higher may use the full range.
If we have a self.window_range of 4 (the default) and range_min is empty, range_max would have contained only at max 4 items to be fetched instead of 8 - I wanted to optimize the number downloaded here if one or the other of the limit were not required.

Maybe it is confusing because of the name: self.window_range is actually in all this patch half the range.

@@ -0,0 +1,367 @@
+from concurrent import futures
+import requests
+from mozlog.structured import get_default_logger
+import copy
+import re
+import threading
+import datetime
+
+from mozregression import errors
+from mozregression.utils import url_links
+
+
+class BuildData(object):
+    """
+    Represents some build data avalaible, designed to be used in
+    bisection.
+
+    It allow the lazy loading of build data, by fetching only lower bound,
+    higher bound and middle points when required.
+
+    As some build folders are not valid - and we can know that only
+    after really fetching data - there is some imprecision on data
+    size which may reduce when you call ensure_limits or mid_point.
+
+    An instance of BuildData acts like a list, ensuring following
+    methods:
+     - len(data) # size
+     - data[1:]  # splice
+     - data[0]   # get data
+     - del data[i] # delete index
+
+    Subclasses must implement :meth:`_create_fetch_task`.
+    """
+    def __init__(self, associated_data, half_window_range=4):
+        self._cache = [[None, ad] for ad in associated_data]
+        self.half_window_range = half_window_range
+        self._logger = get_default_logger('Build Finder')
+
+    def _create_fetch_task(self, executor, i):
+        """
+        Create a task that will really download data for the given index.
+
+        Note that the task can not return None as it is used internally
+        to indicate that data has not been fetched yet.
+
+        If the return value is False the build dir will be considered invalid,
+        and will be discarded.
+
+        Any other value will be acessible via self[index] and the build will
+        be considered valid.
+        """
+        raise NotImplementedError
+
+    def __len__(self):
review_comments.body: I'm not sure if I like that we're re-implementing these list operations to perform on the `_cache` since they're basically already supported. It seems like extra code that's not really making the BuildData class easier to reason about since we need to read the docstring to find that these methods are available. Maybe just providing an accessor to the `_cache` would be simpler.

+        new_data = copy.copy(self)
+        new_data._cache = self._cache[smin:smax]

+        return self._cache[i][0]
+
+    def __delitem__(self, i):
+        del self._cache[i]

+    def _filter_invalid_builds(self):

+    def ensure_limits(self):

+            range_max = []

+            # data to fetch for higher bound will be 8 (full range) instead

+            if range_to_update:

+

review_comments.body: What is the purpose of the lock here? I didn't think mozregression was multithreaded?

review_comments.body:
Mozregression is multithreded since we use futures:
https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/pull/139/files#diff-6b29e041abecfa39ea9b77649ed27207R165
It was only located in inbound, but here it is extended to the search of nightlies valid build.

+            range_max = []

+            # the number of build data which will be fetched.

+"""
+This module defines the configuration needed for nightly and inbound
+fetching for each application.
+"""
+import datetime
+import copy
+
+from mozregression.utils import get_build_regex, ClassRegistry
+from mozregression import errors
+
+class CommonConfig(object):
+    """
+    Define the configuration for both nightly and inbound fetching.
+
+    :attr name: the name of the application
+    """
+    app_name = None
+    def __init__(self, os, bits):
+        self.os = os
+        self.bits = bits
+
+    def build_regex(self):
+        """
+        Returns a string regex that can match a build file on the servers.
+        """
+        return get_build_regex(self.app_name, self.os, self.bits) + '$'
+
+    def build_info_regex(self):
+        """
+        Returns a string regex that can match a build info file (txt)
+        on the servers.
+        """
+        return get_build_regex(self.app_name, self.os, self.bits,
+                               with_ext=False) + r'\.txt$'
+
+    def is_nightly(self):
+        """
+        Returns True if the configuration can be used for nightly fetching.
+        """
+        return isinstance(self, NigthlyConfigMixin)
+
+    def is_inbound(self):
+        """
+        Returns True if the configuration can be used for inbound fetching.
+        """
+        return isinstance(self, InboundConfigMixin)
+
+class NigthlyConfigMixin(object):
+    """
+    Define the nightly-related required configuration.
+    """
+    nightly_base_repo_name = "firefox"
+
+    def nightly_inbound_branch(self, date):
+        raise NotImplementedError
+
+class FireFoxNigthlyConfigMixin(NigthlyConfigMixin):
+    def nightly_inbound_branch(self, date):
+        if date < datetime.date(2008, 6, 17):
+            return "trunk"
+        else:
+            return "mozilla-central"
+
+class ThunderbirdNigthlyConfigMixin(NigthlyConfigMixin):
+    nightly_base_repo_name = 'thunderbird'
+
+    def nightly_inbound_branch(self, date):
+        # sneaking this in here
+        if self.os == "win" and date < datetime.date(2010, 03, 18):
+            # no .zip package for Windows, can't use the installer
+            raise errors.WinTooOldBuildError()
+
+        if date < datetime.date(2008, 7, 26):
+            return "trunk"
+        elif date < datetime.date(2009, 1, 9):
+            return "comm-central"
+        elif date < datetime.date(2010, 8, 21):
+            return "comm-central-trunk"
+        else:
+            return "comm-central"
+
+class B2GNigthlyConfigMixin(NigthlyConfigMixin):

@@ -0,0 +1,41 @@
+---
+layout: default
+title: Quick start
+order: 10
+---
+
+# Quick start
+
+Let's say you just found a bug in the current nightly build and you know that
+bug didn't exist in the nightly from a few weeks ago. You want to find the
+regression range of this bug (the window of commits the bug was introduced in).
+
+To find the range run the mozregression command on the command-line and give
+it a known "good" date with the good argument:
+
+    mozregression --good 2014-12-25
+
+You can also specify the most distant known "bad" nightly date with the bad argument.
+
+    mozregression --good 2014-12-25 --bad 2015-01-07
+
+This will guide you through a bisection, automatically downloading and opening
+nightly builds from various dates (on new, clean profiles) and asking you
+whether the bug exists in them. After doing this a few times you'll get the
+regression range, something like this: 
+
+> Pushlog:
+> https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/pushloghtml?fromchange=636498d041b5&tochange=2a193b7f395c
+
+![My helpful screenshot]({{ site.baseurl }}/images/mozreg.png)
+
+Then mozregression will go on and do the same things with inbound builds
+to get you the smallest possible window range for inbounds.
+
+There is plenty of options for mozregression. See
+
+    mozregression -h
+
+To list them all. Have a look at the
+[usage]({{ "/usage.html" | prepend: site.baseurl }})
+section to go further in mozregression usage!
review_comments.body: to go further in mozregression usage! -> to learn more!

+  Download and install python 2.7 from
+  [ActiveState](http://www.activestate.com/activepython/downloads).
+  It will include pip and set python in your PATH.
review_comments.body:
I assume it is simpler for users, because that includes pip and set python in the PATH. Your point is good though, because mozilla-build does not just install python - it also install everything needed to build mozilla projects - but do we need this now that mozcommitbuilder has been removed ?
Maybe we could keep the mozilla-build step in case we want to build things in a mozregression future, instead of just downloading binaries.

Honestly, I am not a windows user, and i don't really mind one of the two options - still I would prefer a pure python approach personnaly, but maybe just because I know that the activestate python is easy to install and works well. Your choice !

+---
+layout: documentation
+title: Usage
+doc_order: 0
+description: Some common command line options
+---
+
+# Usage of mozregression
+
+Some useful command line usage.
+
+
+## Testing application options
+
+- Run for another application than firefox
+
+       mozregression --app thunderbird
+
+- Run with specific profile
+
+       mozregression --profile=/path/to/profile
+
+- Install addons
+
+       mozregression --addon /path/to/addon --addon /other/addon
+
+-  Forward arguments to tested binary
+
+       mozregression --arg -foreground --arg -P
+
+- Test a 32 bit binary on 64 bit system
+
+       mozregression --bits 32
+
+## Bisecting options
+
+- Bisecting nightlies
+
+       mozregression  --good 2014-12-25 --bad 2015-01-07
+
+- Bisecting nightlies given firefox releases number
+
+       mozregression --good-release 33 --bad-release 34
+
+- Bisecting from a specific nightly project branch
+
+       mozregression  --repo mozilla-aurora
+
+- Bisecting inbound directly
+
+       mozregression --inbound --good-rev 8850aa0f --bad-rev 2a193b7f
+
+- Look for a bug fix instead of a regression (bisect the other way around)
+
+        mozregression --find-fix
+
+- Automate mozregression run (see [Automatic bisection]({{"/documentation/automatic-bisection.html" | prepend: site.baseurl}}))
+
+       mozregression --command 'test-command {binary}'
+
+## Network persistence
+
+- Use a folder to keep downloaded files
+
+        mozregression --persist temp
+
+- Use a cache for http transfer
review_comments.body: Maybe add a parenthetical "(speeds up downloading the same builds a second time)"

@@ -0,0 +1,461 @@
+import copy
+import datetime
+import json
+import re
+
+from mozregression.build_data import NightlyUrlBuilder
+from mozregression.utils import url_links, get_http_session, get_build_regex
+
+
+# modified fetch_configs #
+
+class CommonConfig(object):
+    """
+    Define the configuration for both nightly and inbound fetching.
+
+    :attr name: the name of the application
+    """
+    def __init__(self, app_name):
+        self.app_name = app_name
+
+    def build_regex(self, os, bits):
+        """
+        Returns a string regex that can match a build file on the servers.
+        """
+        if self.app_name == 'fennec':
+            return r".*android-arm\.apk$"
+        return get_build_regex(self.app_name, os, bits) + '$'
+
+    def build_info_regex(self, os, bits):
+        """
+        Returns a string regex that can match a build info file (txt)
+        on the servers.
+        """
+        if self.app_name == 'fennec':
+            return r".*android-arm\.txt"
+        return get_build_regex(self.app_name, os, bits,
+                               with_ext=False) + r'\.txt$'
+
+    def is_nightly(self):
+        """
+        Returns True if the configuration can be used for nightly fetching.
+        """
+        return isinstance(self, NightlyConfigMixin)
+
+    def is_inbound(self):
+        """
+        Returns True if the configuration can be used for inbound fetching.
+        """
+        return isinstance(self, InboundConfigMixin)
+
+
+class NightlyConfigMixin(object):
+    """
+    Define the nightly-related required configuration to find nightly builds.
+
+    A nightly build url is divided in 2 parts here:
+
+    1. the base part as returned by :meth:`get_nighly_base_url`
+    2. the final part, which can be found using :meth:`get_nighly_repo_regex`
+
+    The final part contains a repo name, which is returned by
+    :meth:`get_nightly_repo`.
+
+    Note that subclasses must implement :meth:`_get_nightly_repo` to
+    provide a default value.
+    """
+    nightly_base_repo_name = "firefox"
+    nightly_repo = None
+
+    def get_nighly_base_url(self, date):
+        """
+        Returns the base part of the nightly build url for a given date.
+        """
+        return ("http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/%s/nightly/%04d/%02d/"
+                % (self.nightly_base_repo_name, date.year, date.month))
+
+    def set_nightly_repo(self, repo):
+        """
+        Allow to define the repo name.
+
+        If None, :meth:`_get_nightly_repo` will be called to return a value
+        when :meth:`get_nightly_repo` is called.
+        """
+        self.nightly_repo = repo
+
+    def get_nightly_repo(self, date):
+        """
+        Returns the repo name for a given date.
+        """
+        return self.nightly_repo or self._get_nightly_repo(date)
+
+    def _get_nightly_repo(self, date):
+        """
+        Returns a default repo name for a given date.
+        """
+        raise NotImplementedError
+
+    def get_nightly_repo_regex(self, date):
+        """
+        Returns a string regex that can match the last folder name for a given
+        date.
+        """
+        repo = self.get_nightly_repo(date)
+        return (r'^%04d-%02d-%02d-[\d-]+%s/$'
+                % (date.year, date.month, date.day, repo))
+
+    def can_go_inbound(self):
+        """
+        Indicate if we can bissect inbound from this nightly config.
+        """
+        # we can go on inbound if no nightly repo has been specified.
+        return self.is_inbound() and not self.nightly_repo
+
+
+class FireFoxNightlyConfigMixin(NightlyConfigMixin):
+    def _get_nightly_repo(self, date):
+        if date < datetime.date(2008, 6, 17):
+            return "trunk"
+        else:
+            return "mozilla-central"
+
+
+class ThunderbirdNightlyConfigMixin(NightlyConfigMixin):
+    nightly_base_repo_name = 'thunderbird'
+
+    def _get_nightly_repo(self, date):
+
+        if date < datetime.date(2008, 7, 26):
+            return "trunk"
+        elif date < datetime.date(2009, 1, 9):
+            return "comm-central"
+        elif date < datetime.date(2010, 8, 21):
+            return "comm-central-trunk"
+        else:
+            return "comm-central"
+
+
+class B2GNightlyConfigMixin(NightlyConfigMixin):
+    nightly_base_repo_name = 'b2g'
+
+    def _get_nightly_repo(self, date):
+        return "mozilla-central"
+
+
+class FennecNightlyConfigMixin(NightlyConfigMixin):
+    nightly_base_repo_name = "mobile"
+
+    def _get_nightly_repo(self, date):
+        if date < datetime.date(2014, 12, 6):
+            return "mozilla-central-android"
+        if date < datetime.date(2014, 12, 13):
+            return "mozilla-central-android-api-10"
+        return "mozilla-central-android-api-11"
+
+
+class InboundConfigMixin(object):
+    """
+    Define the inbound-related required configuration.
+    """
+    inbound_branch = 'mozilla-inbound'
+
+    def set_inbound_branch(self, inbound_branch):
+        if inbound_branch:
+            self.inbound_branch = inbound_branch
+
+    def inbound_base_urls(self):
+        raise NotImplementedError
+
+
+class FirefoxInboundConfigMixin(InboundConfigMixin):
+    build_base_os_part = ['linux', 'linux64', 'win32', 'win64', 'macosx64']
+    root_build_base_url = ('http://inbound-archive.pub.build.mozilla.org/pub'
+                           '/mozilla.org/firefox/tinderbox-builds/%s-%s/')
+
+    def inbound_base_urls(self):
+        url = []
+        for os in self.build_base_os_part:
+            url.append(self.root_build_base_url % (self.inbound_branch, os))
+        return url
+
+
+class B2GInboundConfigMixin(FirefoxInboundConfigMixin):
+    inbound_branch = 'b2g-inbound'
+    build_base_os_part = copy.deepcopy(
+        FirefoxInboundConfigMixin.build_base_os_part)
+    build_base_os_part[0] = 'linux32'
+
+    root_build_base_url = ('http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/b2g'
+                           '/tinderbox-builds/%s-%s_gecko/')
+
+
+class FennecInboundConfigMixin(InboundConfigMixin):
+    inbound_branchs = ['mozilla-inbound-android']
+
+    def inbound_base_urls(self):
+        return ["http://inbound-archive.pub.build.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org"
+                "/mobile/tinderbox-builds/%s/" % inbound_branch
+                for inbound_branch in self.inbound_branchs]
+
+    def set_inbound_branch(self, inbound_branch):
+        if inbound_branch:
+            self.inbound_branchs = [inbound_branch]
+
+
+# modified BuildFolderInfoFetcher #
+
+class BuildFolderInfoFetcher(object):
+    """
+    Allow to retrieve information from build folders.
+
+    :param build_regex: a regexp or string regexp that can match the build
+    file.
+    :param build_info_regex: a regexp or string regexp that can match the
+    build info file (.txt).
+    """
+    def __init__(self, build_regex, build_info_regex):
+        self.build_regex = build_regex
+        self.build_info_regex = build_info_regex
+
+    def find_build_info(self, url, read_txt_content=False):
+        """
+        Retrieve information from a build folder url.
+
+        Returns a dict with keys build_url and build_txt_url if respectively
+        a build file and a build info file are found for the url.
+
+        If read_txt_content is True, the dict is updated with data found
+        by calling :meth:`find_build_info_txt`
+        """
+        build_data = []
+        links = url_links(url)
+        for i in range(len(self.build_regex)):
+            data = {}
+            if not url.endswith('/'):
+                url += '/'
+            for link in links:
+                if 'build_url' not in data and self.build_regex[i].match(link):
+                    data['build_url'] = url + link
+                elif 'build_txt_url' not in data and (
+                        self.build_info_regex[i].match(link)):
+                    data['build_txt_url'] = url + link
+            build_data.append(data)
+            if read_txt_content and 'build_txt_url' in data:
+                data.update(self.find_build_info_txt(data['build_txt_url']))
+
+        return build_data
+
+    def find_build_info_txt(self, url):
+        """
+        Retrieve information from a build information txt file.
+
+        Returns a dict with keys date, repository and changeset if information
+        is found.
+        """
+        data = {}
+        response = get_http_session().get(url)
+        date = response.text.splitlines()[0]
+        data['date'] = '%s-%s-%s' % (date[:4], date[4:6], date[6:8])
+        for line in response.text.splitlines():
+            if '/rev/' in line:
+                repository, changeset = line.split('/rev/')
+                data['repository'] = repository
+                data['changeset'] = changeset
+                break
+        if not data:
+            # the txt file could be in an old format:
+            # DATE CHANGESET
+            # we can try to extract that to get the changeset at least.
+            matched = re.match('^\d+ (\w+)$', response.text.strip())
+            if matched:
+                data['changeset'] = matched.group(1)
+        return data
+
+
+class NightlyBuildData():
+    def __init__(self, app_name):
+        self.app_name = app_name
+
+    def good_date(self):
+        """
+        Returns the oldest nightly build date as the good_date
+        """
+        link = 'http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/%s/'
+        'nightly/' % self.app_name
+        if self.app_name == 'fennec':
+            link = "http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/mobile/nightly/"
+        for year in url_links(link):
+            if re.match('20[0-1][0-9]/$', year):
+                oldest_year = link + year
+                for month in url_links(oldest_year):
+                    if re.match('[0-1][0-9]/$', month):
+                        oldest_month = oldest_year + month
+                        for oldest_build in url_links(oldest_month):
+                            if re.match('%s-%s-*' % (
+                                    year[:-1], month[:-1]), oldest_build):
+                                date = oldest_build.split('-')
+                                return '%s-%s-%s' % (date[0], date[1], date[2])
+
+    def get_regex(self):
+        """
+        Returns build_regex and build_info_regex
+        """
+        common_config = CommonConfig(self.app_name)
+        OS = ['win', 'linux', 'mac']
+        BITS = [32, 64]
+        build_regex = []
+        build_info_regex = []
+
+        for os in OS:
+            for bits in BITS:
+                build_regex.append(re.compile(
+                    common_config.build_regex(os, bits)))
+                build_info_regex.append(re.compile(
+                    common_config.build_info_regex(os, bits)))
+                if os == 'mac':
+                    break
+        return build_regex, build_info_regex
+
+    def get_nightly_info(self):
+        """
+        Gets nightly build info of given app_name
+        """
+        good_date = datetime.datetime.strptime(
+            self.good_date(), "%Y-%m-%d").date()
+        bad_date = datetime.datetime.now().date()
+        day_count = (bad_date - good_date).days + 1
+        dates = []
+        for n in range(day_count):
+            dates.append(good_date + datetime.timedelta(n))
+
+        build_regex, build_info_regex = self.get_regex()
+        build_info_folder = BuildFolderInfoFetcher(
+            build_regex, build_info_regex)
+
+        if self.app_name == 'firefox':
+            app = FireFoxNightlyConfigMixin()
+        elif self.app_name == 'thunderbird':
+            app = ThunderbirdNightlyConfigMixin()
+        elif self.app_name == 'b2g':
+            app = B2GNightlyConfigMixin()
+        elif self.app_name == 'fennec':
+            app = FennecNightlyConfigMixin()
+
+        nightly_builder = NightlyUrlBuilder(app)
+
+        nightly_info = []
+
+        for date in dates:
+            url = nightly_builder.get_urls(date)[0]
+            print 'url:', url
+            build_info = build_info_folder.find_build_info(url)
+            # print 'build_info:',build_info
+            for builds in build_info:
+                result = {}
+                if 'build_txt_url' not in builds:
+                    continue
+                build_info_text = build_info_folder.find_build_info_txt(
+                    builds['build_txt_url'])
+                result['build_url'] = builds['build_url']
+                result['date'] = str(date)
+                result['changeset'] = build_info_text['changeset']
+                result['repository'] = build_info_text['repository']
+                nightly_info.append(result)
+
+        return nightly_info
+
+    def build_json_files(self):
+        j = json.dumps(self.get_nightly_info(), indent=2)
+        f = open('nightly_%s.json' % self.app_name, 'w')
+        print >> f, j
+        f.close
+
+
+class InboundBuildData():
+    def __init__(self, app_name):
+        self.app_name = app_name
+
+    def get_regex(self, url):
+        """
+        Returns build_regex and build_info_regex
+        """
+        common_config = CommonConfig(self.app_name)
+        if 'linux64' in url:
+            return (
+                [re.compile(common_config.build_regex('linux', 64))],
+                [re.compile(common_config.build_info_regex('linux', 64))])
+        elif 'linux' in url:

+                [re.compile(common_config.build_regex('linux', 32))],

+            return (
+                [re.compile(common_config.build_regex('win', 32))],
+                [re.compile(common_config.build_info_regex('win', 32))])
+        elif 'win64' in url:
+            return (
+                [re.compile(common_config.build_regex('win', 64))],

  conf = tempfile.mkstemp()

@@ -247,10 +240,12 @@ def cli(argv=None):
         # can go to inbound from nightly.
         fetch_config.set_inbound_branch(options.inbound_branch)
 
-    if options.inbound:
+    # bisect inbound if last good revision and first bad revision are set
+    if (options.first_bad_revision and options.last_good_revision):
review_comments.body:
You have to use a "or" condition here instead of "and". If there is a missing rev option (--good-rev or --bad-rev) it wil be handled in the bisect_inbound function (https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/blob/9a99d82071f383147b14899b64c96bad467e6bd6/mozregression/main.py#L217).
if you don't do that, a user that only use "mozregression --good-rev 123" for example will default to nightly bisection instead of inbound which is not really user-friendly.

Hm, not sure to understand what you are trying to do here...
I think that the python path "D:\\Python27" must be the configurable part. For this, you can do something like
python_lib_path = os.path.join(
    os.getenv('MOZREGUI_PYTHONPATH', "C:\\Python27"),

Thiw way one can call this on the windows shell:
set MOZREGUI_PYTHONPATH=D:\Python27
python build.by bundle

+    icon_arg = '--icon=wininst/app_icon.ico '
+    target_arg = '--target-name=mozregression-gui.exe --target-dir=dist'
+    base_name = '--base-name=Win32GUI '
+    arg = icon_arg + base_name + include_path + target_arg
+    call(sys.executable, py_script('cxfreeze'), arg, 'mozregui/main.py')
review_comments.body:
call() require you to list the arguments one by one - that is:
call('cd', 'mozregui')
but you can put them in a list and then use \* (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3394835/args-and-kwargs)
args = ['cd', 'mozregui']
call(*args)

So here you should build args this way for example:
args = []
args.append('--icon=wininst/app_icon.ico')  # note: no leading space
args.append('--base-name=Win32GUI')
...
args.append('mozregui/main.py')
call(sys.executable, py_script('cxfreeze'), *args)

A good pythonic alternative is to use the "with statement" (http://effbot.org/zone/python-with-statement.htm). It is safer because the tar file will be closed even if there is an issue - and it is shorter to write. Something like:

```
with tarfile.open('mozregression-gui.tar.gz', 'w:gz') as release_tar:
    release_tar.add(r'dist/')
```

You can look at the example section and search for the one using with: https://docs.python.org/2/library/tarfile.html#examples

review_comments.body:
hmm, according to the doc (http://mozbase.readthedocs.org/en/latest/mozlog_structured.html#data-format), it would be possible to have log levels like CRITICAL, ERROR, WARNING, INFO, DEBUG. So this would crash if we (or one of mozregression dependency) use CRITICAL or ERROR as it is not handled. You could set the same color as for WARNING though.

Also, I think it is possible for somebody using mozlog to add its own level. so we should try to get the color from the COLORS dict - and only apply the color if we find one for the given level.

+---
+title:  "Release 0.41"
+author: Julien Pagès
+---
+
+mozregression 0.41 fixes [bug 1185756], which caused the following
+warning on Windows:
+
+    WindowsError: [Error 32] The process cannot access the file
+    because it is being used by another process
+
+Also, mozregression is now more tolerant when facing failures like
+a build not installable or a crash from the tested application
+(see [bug 1192485]).
+
+And finally, when using mozregression with a custom profile
+it won't be modified anymore (see [bug 999009]). This bug was here
+for a long time - thanks to Jonathan Pigree for his help in fixing this!

+from PyQt4.QtCore import QAbstractListModel, QModelIndex, Qt, \
+    pyqtSlot as Slot
+from PyQt4.QtGui import QWidget, QFileDialog
+from mozregui.ui.addons_editor import Ui_AddonsEditor
+
+
+class AddonsMode(QAbstractListModel):
+    """
+    A Qt model that can edit addons path.
+    """
+
+    def __init__(self, parent=None):
+        QAbstractListModel.__init__(self, parent)
+        self.addonsPath = []
+
+    def rowCount(self, index=QModelIndex()):
+        return len(self.addonsPath)
+
+    def data(self, index, role=Qt.DisplayRole):
+        if role == Qt.DisplayRole:
+            if index.row() == 0:
+                return None
+            else:
+                return repr(self.addonsPath[index.row()])
+
+    def setData(self, index, new_value, role=Qt.EditRole):
+        path = str(new_value.toString())
+        self.addonsPath[index.row()] = path
+        return True
+
+    def headerData(self, section, orientation, role=Qt.DisplayRole):
+        if role == Qt.DisplayRole and orientation == Qt.Horizontal:
+            return 'path'[section]
+
+    def flags(self, index):
+        return Qt.ItemIsSelectable | Qt.ItemIsEditable | Qt.ItemIsEnabled
+
+    def add_addons_from_file(self, addons):
+        if addons:
+            path = len(self.addonsPath)
+            self.beginInsertRows(QModelIndex(), path,
+                                 path + len(addons) - 1)
+            self.addonsPath.extend(str(addons))
review_comments.body:
I think you just need to use 'append' instead of 'extend'. But I think you misunderstood what a addon is. An addon for firefox is an extension (I think you new that but let's be clear), https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/. Here we should give a list of addons, so I would say a list of file end each file name ends with '*.xpi'.

I think that the Profile class we use can also take a folder name that contains addons - but I am not sure, and this won't do us any good from the gui. I think we should just allow the user to select one or more *.xpi files.

Does that help ?
